urn:contentItem:5YNR-P9D1-F0J6-J14K-00000-00Recovery continues in the Upper Murray2020-04-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisRecovery continues in the Upper MurrayVivienne Jones

More than 260 kilometres of fencing has been replaced by Forest Fire Management Victoria since the Upper Murray bushfires earlier this year.

And the recovery effort is ongoing with teams continuing to assist with fencing, track clearing and hazardous tree removal.

Upper Murray district manager Dave Jenson said this had been a "very difficult time" and communities across the region had had a lot to deal with

"We want to reassure the community that our crews are continuing with bushfire recovery efforts, both safely out in the field and remotely, to ensure these priority programs continue," he said.

Mr Jenson said there had been 101 successful fencing funding applications completed.

"Many landowners that have had fencing affected have still not taken up the opportunity for funding, so I encourage people to contact us," he said.

urn:contentItem:6061-N8P1-JD34-V0VG-00000-00Victorian firewood season coming to an end2020-06-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisVictorian firewood season coming to an end

The autumn firewood collection season will come to a close at the end of the month.

From July 1, it will be illegal to collect firewood from public land.

Until then, a person can collect a maximum of two cubic metres of firewood per day, and may collect up to 16 cubic metres per household per financial year.

"Limits are in place to prevent households stockpiling large volumes of firewood from public land and denying others a supply," Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said.

Firewood can only be collected from specific areas, of which there are many across central Victoria.

Penalties for breaches of the law can include fines of more than $8000 and even imprisonment.

Information on designated collection areas can be found online.

urn:contentItem:5YS9-BFR1-JD34-V3KM-00000-00Terrick Terrick park burn off planned2020-04-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisTerrick Terrick park burn off planned

A planned burn will be carried out this week on 57 hectares of Terrick Terrick National Park.

The burn is scheduled to take place between 10am on Tuesday, 28 April and 8pm on Friday, 1 May.

The burn location is listed as Terrick Terrick National Park Torrumbarry Block 493, 12 kilometres south of Torrumbarry.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA advises that people may see smoke from this burn until Tuesday, 5 May and that smoke may be visited from Torrumbarry, Wharparilla, Rosylnmead and Pine Grove.

FFMV and the CFA says that road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke and signs may be in place to slow traffic.

If you are experiencing any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, the Department of Health and Human Services advises that you should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

urn:contentItem:5Y5S-R231-JD34-V3CM-00000-00Bega Valley fire emergency: the devastation in pictures2020-01-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisBega Valley fire emergency: the devastation in pictures

A number of fires have ripped through several parts of the Bega Valley and continue to be an ongoing threat to communities despite the welcome reprieve of rain on Monday.

Cobargo and Quaama have been ravaged by the Badja State forest fire, which sadly took two lives of Cobargo farmers who stayed to defend their home.

Bemboka continues to face fire threat from the Werri Berri fire with crews working to defend homes.

South areas of Kiah, Wonboyn and neighbouring Ben Boyd National Park have also been scorched and there are fears for historic buildings and the chip mill, while Towamba, Burragate, Eden and Nethercote remain under threat.

urn:contentItem:60BK-TF11-F0JP-W25W-00000-00THE WAY WE WERE2020-07-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisBOOMERPg. 24THE WAY WE WEREAndrew O'Grady

What was making news in The Advertiser 50 years ago this week. Compiled by Andrew O'Grady

JULY 13, 1970 The Commonwealth Forestry Bureau is to experiment with a forest fire simulator following a move by SA.

The suggestion was put forward by the Minister of Agriculture (Mr. Casey) at a conference in Perth of the Australian Forestry Council.

The Minister, who returned to Adelaide from the conference last night, said the other States had shown great interest in the simulator as a means of keeping foresters and firefighters in training.

"Dr. Cromer, the director-general of the Forestry Bureau, has indicated he is very interested in this project and will conduct experiments with the simulator," Mr. Casey said.

The US-designed simulator, which costs between $3,000 and $4,000 consists of four slide projectors focused on a single screen.

By moving one transparency across another, the effect of real smoke and fire is created. It is used in a heated room with sound effects and trainees use a radio system to fight the "fire."

urn:contentItem:60N1-WG61-F0J6-J3S0-00000-00Pig cull wipes out 64 pests in North East region as part of three year plan2020-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNATIONALPg. 14Pig cull wipes out 64 pests in North East region as part of three year planVivienne Jones

More than 60 feral pigs were killed on public land in targeted locations across north-east Victoria.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Hume planning manager invasive species David Pasztaleniec said 64 of the pests were trapped and killed, many of them pregnant, in state forests and national parks in the Tatong, Samaria and Strathbogie areas.

"Feral pigs pose a serious threat to agriculture productivity and the environment, so this work is critical in protecting the land," he said.

"We are also working with landowners, especially those who adjoin public land, to better understand the level of impacts the pigs are having."

Mr Pasztaleniec said the three-year project used remote cameras and satellite tracking to pinpoint pig movements.

"They are a pest for farmers, because they can carry a number of diseases which can kill livestock and their feeding behaviour can heavily degrade agricultural land," he said

urn:contentItem:600C-4K51-F0JP-W0FC-00000-00Planned burns at Anglesea2020-05-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Planned burns at AngleseaNatalee Kerr

A SERIES of planned burns in Anglesea has begun in a bid to maintain the health of its unique ecosystem.

The burns will take place over two months, covering more than 340ha north of Anglesea and Aireys Inlet.

Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) Otway district manager David Roberts said without fire the ecosystem got crowded out by encroaching taller tree species.

"We know that heath thrives on fire, and parts of the Anglesea Heath haven't been exposed to fire since Ash Wednesday, more than 30 years go," he said.

"Applying fire restores and maintains an open structure in the heath, which in turns supports a wide range of native plants and wildlife." The Anglesea Heath is home to about one-quarter of Victoria's plant species and threatened wildlife.

Smoke may be seen from Anglesea, Aireys Inlet and surrounding areas and traffic management will be in place along key roads.

More information about planned burns at vic.gov.au/plannedburns or call 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:5YY3-9H21-F0JP-W478-00000-00FIREMAN'S KILLER IN TEARS2020-05-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 19FIREMAN'S KILLER IN TEARSGenevieve Alison

A DRUG driver has cried as he admitted to causing a deadly crash, which killed a firefighter during the summer's bushfire disaster.

Novak Selby, 46, pleaded guilty to dangerous driving causing the death of Forest Fire Management Victoria's firefighter Mat Kavanagh, 43, near Mansfield on January 3 this year.

Mr Kavanagh, a father of two, had worked for FFMV for more than a decade and had been putting out unattended campfires before the head-on collision with Selby's four wheel drive on the Goulburn Valley Highway in Thornton.

Selby entered his guilty plea via videolink from prison after he was refused bail in March this year.

The court heard police were concerned the Alexandra man would "go bush" if released from custody.

Selby is also charged with driving with cannabis in his system. Selby was allegedly driving on the wrong side of the road when he hit the truck's passenger side, killing Mr Kavanagh. Selby was also injured and spent three days in hospital.

urn:contentItem:5Y5W-DS41-F0J6-J324-00000-00Upgrade of roads to assist with risk2020-02-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Upgrade of roads to assist with risk

ROADS within the Grampians have benefited from part of the $273.2 million package to reduce the risk and severity of bushfires across Victoria. Ten new creek crossings were constructed along Harrop's Track from Mooralla to its continuation onto Red Rock Road at Glenisla.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Wimmera district manager Glenn Rudolph said an important component of the Reducing Bushfire Risk program was to ensure adequate road capacity to respond quickly and safely to bushfires in state forests and national parks this summer.

"To do that, we've needed to ensure we can get all emergency response vehicles including larger fire trucks and massive machinery, such as excavators and bulldozers, on-site more quickly to construct fire containment lines and natural barriers," Mr Rudolph said.

urn:contentItem:5YS9-BFR1-JD34-V3KG-00000-00Victorian bushfire season finishes2020-04-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisVictorian bushfire season finishesTara Cosoleto

CENTRAL Victorians should remain vigilant despite the fire season coming to a close, a fire chief says.

The unprecedented fire season finished on Monday. More than 1.5 million hectares of land was burnt across the state this summer.

Five people were killed in blazes that tore through north west Victoria and East Gippsland, while more than 500 homes were destroyed.

Acting Assistant Chief Fire Officer Chris Jacobsen said apart from the Code Red day on November 21, this region was left mostly unscathed.

"It was a summer full of potential," he said. "That potential was realised in some parts of the state.

"Here in District 2, we had some fires throughout the season but luckily through the actions of people in central Victoria, and the CFA and Forest Fire Management crews, we were able to limit the amount of damage."

Commander Jacobsen said while the bushfire season had ended, people should continue to register burn-offs and tell neighbours if they're planning a burn.

"Here in District 2, we had some fires throughout the season but luckily through the actions of people in central Victoria, and the CFA and Forest Fire Management crews, we were able to limit the amount of damage."

Commander Jacobsen said while the bushfire season had ended, people should continue to register burn-offs and tell neighbours if they're planning a burn.

Tasmania Fire Service crews were on the scene at a reported structure fire in Devonport yesterday.

However, the fire at the grain silos caused no damage to the outside of the building, according to the Tasmania Fire Service.

An electrical fault caused a fire to a conveyor belt at Devonport grain silo, a TFS spokeswoman said.

A TFS spokeswoman said a small fire started on a conveyor belt at the silos on Formby Rd, Devonport but no part of the building was affected by the blaze.

The spokeswoman said crews were on scene from 11am for a few hours while the area was made safe.

The current fire danger rating for Tasmania is presently low to moderate according to the MacArthur's Forest Fire Danger Index which is calculated from data sourced from the Bureau of Meteorology on temperature, wind speed, humidity, rainfall and drought factor.

NORTH American firefighters have been arriving in Australia since early last month to help the country's bushfire crisis, with more to be deployed.

For the first time since 2010, the US is sending firefighters while Canada is sending fire experts to Australia for the first time. The National Interagency Fire Centre, the US Government agency that co-ordinates international deployment of firefighters, says about 100 American firefighters have been sent over the past four weeks, with 50 to 60 more to be dispatched tomorrow.Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre duty officer Stephen Tulle said 84 Canadian fire experts were stationed in Queensland and NSW on a six-week deployment. Canadians are keen to repay Australian firies' help during the 2017 and 2018 blazes in British Columbia province.

urn:contentItem:5YXW-CFT1-JC0X-K080-00000-00VIC:Vic driver guilty over firefighter death2020-05-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Vic driver guilty over firefighter deathMELBOURNE May 19

  A Victorian driver has wept after pleading guilty over a crash that killed a firefighter during bushfires in January.
   Novak John Selby admitted to dangerous driving causing death over the crash on the Goulburn Valley Highway at Thornton on January 3.


   Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighter Mat Kavanagh died in the crash after the passenger side of the truck was hit.
   "Guilty, your honour," 46-year-old Selby told Melbourne Magistrates Court before he wiped his eyes and put his head in his hands.
   The firefighter was on his way to a different zone after battling blazes in the Big River area when he was killed.
   Selby spent three days in hospital after the crash before he was discharged and interviewed over the allegations.
   A court was previously told he appeared "genuinely upset" over the crash and suffered post-traumatic stress disorder because of the Black Saturday bushfires.
   Selby had been living at Narbethong, near Marysville, when the bushfires ripped through the area.
   A pre-sentence hearing will be held in August.

urn:contentItem:5YJS-3XC1-F0J6-J2CG-00000-00Dryness impacting planned burns2020-04-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Dryness impacting planned burnsHayley Elg

Forest Fire Management Victoria is continuing to forge ahead with its planned fuel reduction burns across the Grampians region, despite temperamental weather conditions and social distancing guidelines.

Due to an underlying dryness, there have been limited opportunities for FFMV to conduct its planned burning schedule this autumn. According to FFMV, planned burning is an important part of the fuel management strategy in the Grampians Region. Following forecast rain this weekend, it is hoped that extended stable weather conditions will allow for more planned burns to be carried out. So far this season, it has conducted 13 burns over more than 1200 hectares. Its mechanical fuel management program, which includes slashing, mulching and mowing, has seen an additional 2000 hectares treated.

FFMV Acting Deputy Chief Fire Officer, Peter Kambouris, said the current health advice allowed FFMV's planned burning program to continue as normal for now. All activities are being conducted in line with social distancing requirements.

urn:contentItem:5Y0H-GK91-F0JP-W1H8-00000-00Farewell for firey2020-01-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Farewell for fireyMONIQUE HORE

"BUSHFIRE Bill", a veteran firefighter killed in Victoria's fire disaster, will be farewelled next week.

Bill Slade, 60, was killed by a falling tree at Anglers Rest, near Omeo, on Saturday while working with a forest fire management taskforce to consolidate the fire edge.

His family has spoken of its heartbreak in touching tributes published in yesterday's (Herald Sun.

His wife, Carol, said that she "never thought that this would be something that would be happening to us".

"You gave us so much, and have been my rock for nearly 40 years," she said. His daughter Stephanie said she would miss the way her dad laughed at her "below average jokes", while son Ethan paid tribute to "an amazing man".He will be farewelled on Wednesday at an 11am service at Wonthaggi State Coal Mine.

urn:contentItem:5Y09-H9D1-F0JP-W1XG-00000-00Grandfather fifth person killed in Victorian blazes2020-01-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Grandfather fifth person killed in Victorian blazesMONIQUE HORE, KIERAN ROONEY

A BELOVED grandfather killed on the Gippsland fireground in Victoria has been named as the fifth victim of that state's bushfire disaster.

David Moresi, (inset) a Forest Fire Management contractor, died on November 30 in a vehicle rollover at W Tree in East Gippsland.

After supervising bulldozers digging fire breaks, his car rolled as he drove through the fire ground at the end of his shift.

Daughter Kelly Douglass said her father "would get in to help anyone who needed it".

"He was a really good and caring dad, he loved his grandkids and would do anything for them," she said.The 69-year-old and his wife, Judi, had been together since they were 15, and Ms Douglass said the devastated family were "struggling" in the wake of his death.

A number of fires have ripped through several parts of the Bega Valley and continue to be an ongoing threat to communities despite the welcome reprieve of rain on Monday.

Cobargo and Quaama have been ravaged by the Badja forest fire, which sadly took two lives of Cobargo farmers who stayed to defend their home.

Bemboka continues to face fire threat from the Werri Berri fire with crews working to defend homes.

South areas of Kiah, Wonboyn and neighbouring Ben Boyd National Park have also been scorched and there are fears for historic buildings and the chip mill, while Towamba, Burragate, Eden and Nethercote remain under threat.

urn:contentItem:5Y33-WCC1-F0JP-W4GS-00000-00Works start to reduce fire risk2020-01-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Works start to reduce fire risk

IN the wake of community concern around the fire risk at the Ocean Grove Nature -Reserve, Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMV) will conduct -another round of fuel management work this week.

Mulching of woody weeds and native woody species will take place within the reserve to reduce the bushfire risk and enhance the health of the coastal woodland ecosystem.

FFMV Otway district manager David Roberts said the work would include mulching a 40m strip on Grubb Rd.

"Mulching is the most effective way to reduce fuels in this reserve because we can target specific species and protect the larger trees," Mr Roberts said.

"We will be mulching to reduce fuel levels and help open up this section of the reserve to be more like the original natural grassy woodland setting."Mulching will taking about 10"days, with crews working throughout the reserve.

urn:contentItem:6061-N8P1-JD34-V0Y0-00000-00When you can stop collecting firewood from public land2020-06-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisWhen you can stop collecting firewood from public land

The autumn firewood collection season will come to a close at the end of the month.

From July 1, it will be illegal to collect firewood from public land.

Until then, a person can collect a maximum of two cubic metres of firewood per day, and may collect up to 16 cubic metres per household per financial year.

"Limits are in place to prevent households stockpiling large volumes of firewood from public land and denying others a supply," Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said.

LISTEN: Don't miss The Courier's first podcast, 'Off The Record'. Episode one reflects on the tragic death of beloved footballer Lachie Poulter, speaking to those closest to him

Firewood can only be collected from specific areas - including Niggle Road in Creswick, Hermit Track in Stevewood, Beaufort-Carngham Road and Farley Lane in Beaufort and Incolls Road in Enfield.

Penalties for breaches of the law can include fines of more than $8000 and even imprisonment.

Information on designated collection areas can be found online.

urn:contentItem:5Y5N-FJF1-JD34-V4DP-00000-00Thunderstorms bring rain and fire to parts of the Wimmera2020-02-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Thunderstorms bring rain and fire to parts of the WimmeraEliza Berlage

Severe thunderstorms on Thursday evening brought heavy rain to parts of the Wimmera, with reports of flooding in Birchip and fires in Hopetoun and Banyan.

The Country Fire Authority issued community information for haystack fires at Nevilles Road in Hopetoun, and on Collins Road in Banyan.

The CFA said there was no immediate threat to the community and no action was required.

The rain hit the north of the region the hardest with multiple calls for assistance from houses in Birchip.

In the 24 hours to 9am on Friday, Hopetoun received 58 millimetres of rain, Jeparit 39 millimetres, Donald 13 millimetres and Woomelang 11.

Across the weekend, Horsham received 3.4 millimetres, Nhill 10.2 and Longerenong 1.6.

On Sunday morning, Forest Fire Management Victoria crews brought a bushfire in Paradise Flora and Fauna Reserve near Yaapeet under control. A State Control Centre spokeswoman said the fire had burnt 0.3 of a hectare when it was controlled at 10.15am.

urn:contentItem:5YFJ-KWS1-JD3N-51KH-00000-00Controlled burn to ease threat2020-03-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 14Controlled burn to ease threat

A 415ha planned burn in the Otways southwest of Geelong is continuing. About 70 firefighters started the operation on Sunday in lowland forest near Gellibrand, about 100km from Geelong.

Forest Fire Management Victoria incident controller Stephanie Ryan said mild temperatures and low winds were ideal for planed burns.

"By reducing fuel loads across this area, the planned burn is designed to reduce the size, intensity and impact of potential fires approaching Gellibrand from the west," Ms Ryan said.

"We understand that smoke from planned burning may cause concern, but we are undertaking every opportunity to burn while conditions allow and it is safe to do so." Some hard to access areas due to be burnt will be ignited and monitored from the air. Once the planned burn is completed, crews will patrol the area for several days until it is declared safe.

The planned burn is about 10km from the Carlisle River where a 350ha fire sparked by lighting broke out this year.For more information, go to vic.gov.au/plannedburns or call 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:5YD2-JM91-JD3N-52DW-00000-00Coast burn-offs to cut bushfire risk2020-03-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Coast burn-offs to cut bushfire riskNATALEE KERR

LARGE swathes of land near Anglesea, Aireys Inlet and Lorne are set to burn from this month as part of planned operations to reduce bushfire risk along the Surf Coast.

The burns will reduce bushfire fuel and provide protection for homes, Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) says.

"Staff would like to acknowledge that this has been an incredibly busy fire season across the state," FFMVic said.

"The delivery of the fuel management program is a very important part of protecting our communities from bushfires.

"We will endeavour to minimise impacts while we carry out these works." The autumn program will focus on reducing fuel loads in the Otway district, including grasslands near Colac, Gellibrand and Forrest.

Larger planned burns up to 1900ha in size are also set to be conducted in bushland behind Lorne, Aireys Inlet and Anglesea.

FFMVic said the works helped to lessen the fuel load or modify fuel structure to -reduce the risk of a bushfire impact, speed and intensity.For more information visit plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au.

urn:contentItem:5XYT-7RD1-DXX7-H52N-00000-00Man charged over crash that killed Victorian firefighter Mat Kavanagh2020-01-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisMan charged over crash that killed Victorian firefighter Mat Kavanagh

Police have charged a man with dangerous driving causing death in relation to the road crash that killed Victorian firefighter Mat Kavanagh.

Mr Kavanagh, 43, and his Forest Fire Management Victoria colleague were involved in a two-vehicle crash on the Goulburn Valley Highway on January 3.

The father-of-two was remembered as a "well-loved guy" who was doing the "critical work" of putting out unattended campfires the day he died.

Authorities confirmed on Friday that his death was fire-related.

Police said a car and a ute collided head-on along the Goulburn Valley Highway about 1:45pm.

Mr Kavanagh died at the scene and his colleague, a 47-year-old Narbethong man, was treated in hospital.

The driver of the car, a 46-year-old Alexandra man, was airlifted to hospital in a critical condition.

He was today charged with dangerous driving causing death.

He has been remanded to appear at Wangaratta Magistrates' Court on April 28.

From - Page 1 Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA crews were working at the fire scene on Sunday.

"A majority of the work to be done is along the creek line where trees and heavier fuel loads are," CFA District 2 duty officer John Breaks said.

"That has been the focus overnight and this morning."

Roads were reopened on Sunday morning after fire crews had ensured the fire wouldn't flare up again.

Mr Houlahan said outbreaks could occur and that CFA crews worked for about five hours on Saturday night.

"With the strong southerly winds and the hot temperatures, we're still getting outbreaks but we have sufficient crews to contain it to the area of origin at this stage," he said on Saturday evening.

"Forty CFA tankers, 15 CFA support and 25 forest firefighting units (were on scene on Saturday)."

A number of people also were in the area on Saturday to help move animals from the Bendigo Animal Welfare Community Services.

urn:contentItem:5Y6F-X3K1-DY17-M296-00000-00Weather may make Pialligo fire difficult to control2020-01-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisWeather may make Pialligo fire difficult to control

The Pialligo fire early this morning. Photo: Andrew Campbell.

NO properties are under threat from the Pialligo Redwood Forest fire, but the Emergency Services Agency says that under current weather conditions the fire may become difficult to control. The 147-hectare fire is under control and firefighters are on scene assisted by aerial water-bombing and surveillance of the fire ground. The ACT has a declared total fire ban in deference to the climbing temperatures and extremely windy conditions. The ESA is rating the Pialligo fire at "advice" level and warns that people in Beard, Oaks Estate and West Queanbeyan (including Crestwood) could be affected by a bushfire that started yesterday (January 22) at Pialligo Redwood Forest. The agency is reminding them that they need to remain alert and know what to do if threatened by fire. The ESA also asks people to take care when travelling along Pialligo Avenue as emergency service vehicles and personnel are working in the area. Oaks Estate Road remains closed while crews are on scene. People in the area may be affected by smoke, which could reduce visibility and air quality.

urn:contentItem:5XYS-YCW1-JD3N-502W-00000-00Victorian victims get tax relief2020-01-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11Victorian victims get tax reliefGenevieve Alison and Aneeka Simonis

VICTORIAN families and businesses devastated by the bushfires will be given immediate tax relief, as a veteran firefighter killed while on duty is remembered as a hero.

The State Government is promising a raft of tax breaks, with businesses and residents whose properties were destroyed or substantially damaged exempt from their 2020 land tax.

Treasurer Tim Pallas said: "The last thing people need to worry about when they are rebuilding after bushfires is the next tax bill coming in." It comes as Bill Slade, 60, was yesterday remembered as a much-loved friend and selfless firefighter with more than four decades of service to Parks Victoria and Forest Fire Management.

He was killed by a falling tree while working to contain a fire edge at Angler's Rest near Omeo on Saturday, taking the state's bushfire death toll to four."He was wonderful, there wasn't a soul that didn't love him," said niece Rachel Coyne. "He was hard working and adored his family."

urn:contentItem:5Y03-YWY1-DYG0-91TN-00000-00VIC:Third Victorian fire death confirmed2020-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Third Victorian fire death confirmedMELBOURNE Jan 6

  A third person is confirmed to have died in Victoria's bushfires.
    Forest Fires Management worker Matt Kavanagh, 43, died when his vehicle crashed on the Goulburn Valley Highway on January 3.


   Emergency Services Minister Lisa Neville confirmed on Friday his death was related to the bushfires, following a police investigation.
   "Matt was a dedicated and respected member of Forest Fire Management Victoria for around 10 years and was on duty as a part of our fire response on the day," she told reporters.
   "He's being remembered for his friendly and welcoming nature, his passion for the environment and nature and his love of fly fishing."
   "It's a devastating loss for everybody in the sector but for those people who knew Matt it's going to take a long time, I can't imagine what they are going through,"Forest Fires Management Chief Fire Officer Chris Hardman said.
   A colleague was taken to hospital following the accident and has since been released.
   Mick Roberts from Buchan and Maramingo Creek man Fred Becker were also killed while battling bushfires this season.

urn:contentItem:5Y09-H9D1-F0JP-W0P7-00000-00OTWAYS BURN AFTER LIGHTNING STRIKES2020-01-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5OTWAYS BURN AFTER LIGHTNING STRIKESCHAD VAN ESTROP

FIREFIGHTERS were last night battling an out-of-control 180ha bushfire in the Otways that was sparked by lightning.

The fire, fought by 20 crews in difficult-to-reach terrain, yesterday afternoon prompted authorities to tell Gellibrand residents to leave immediately.

The fire broke out near the Carlisle River just after 2.30pm and last night it had spread northeast towards Gellibrand.

As the Geelong Advertiser went to press, the CFA said two other smaller fires within 5km of Gellibrand also sparked by lightning yesterday were yet to be brought under control.

The CFA's watch and act message issued for Gellibrand residents yesterday warned conditions could change quickly.

"Don't wait, leaving now is the safest option - conditions may change and get worse very quickly," the message read.

Residents were urged to monitor warnings to act quickly if the situation changed and to review their fire plan.

CFA firefighters worked with Forest Fire Management Victoria officers to control the fires.If you need medical advice for burns or exposure to smoke, seek a doctor or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024. Anyone experiencing wheezing, chest tightness and difficulty breathing should call 000.

urn:contentItem:5XYW-H1T1-F0JP-W3K8-00000-00Man charged over crash that killed firefighter2020-01-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Man charged over crash that killed firefighter

POLICE have charged a man with dangerous driving causing death after a firefighter was killed responding to the devastating East Gippsland bushfires.

Forest management firefighter Mat Kavanagh, 43, died when the ute he was a passenger in crashed into a car at Thornton, near Mansfield, on January 3. Mr Kavanagh had -helped put out seven unattended campfires before the head-on collision on the Goulburn Valley Highway at 1.45pm.

The father of two will be farewelled by family and friends in a funeral service today.

Major Collision Investigation Unit detectives have now charged a 46-year-old Alexandra man over the fatal crash. The accused, who was driving the car that crashed into the firefighters' ute, was flown to hospital in a critical condition. He has been remanded in custody to appear at Wangaratta Magistrates Court on April 28.

The 47-year-old Narbethong driver of the firefighters' ute was taken to hospital in a serious condition.Mr Kavanagh's wife Jude paid tribute to her husband as "positive, happy, smart, passionate, funny and loyal". Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said the 10-year veteran's death had devastated his loved ones and colleagues.

urn:contentItem:5Y6F-X3K1-DY17-M291-00000-00Pialligo fire downgraded but still 'out of control'2020-01-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisPialligo fire downgraded but still 'out of control'

The Pialligo Redwood Forest fire seen from Queanbeyan.

AN OUT-of-control bushfire, moving in an easterly direction from the Pialligo Redwood Forest is approaching the suburbs of Beard, Oaks Estate and West Queanbeyan and, according to an earlier concern of the Emergency Services Agency, posed a threat to all lives directly in its path. The 84-hectare fire has been downgraded from "emergency" to "watch and act" but is still listed as "out of control". Smoke plumes could be seen from as far away as Bungendore. Pialligo Avenue is closed from Scherger Drive to Oaks Estate Road. The Queanbeyan Railway Line has been closed. Railway Road at Oaks Estate and Railway Street at Norse Road is closed. The community is asked to avoid the area. Earlier, the ESA had declared an "emergency" warning and advised residents it was too late to leave and that they were in danger and needed to seek immediate shelter as the fire approached. "People in streets north of Uriarra Road should leave now towards David Campese Oval if safe to do so," the ESA said. "Fire crews may not be able to protect you and your property. Do not expect a firefighter at your door: seek shelter now".

urn:contentItem:5Y06-VY31-DXX7-H24J-00000-00Victorian bushfires death toll rises as authorities confirm contractor's death was fire-related2020-01-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisVictorian bushfires death toll rises as authorities confirm contractor's death was fire-related

Victorian authorities have confirmed a fifth person has died during the state's bushfire crisis.

David Moresi, who was a contractor working at the Gelantipy fire in East Gippsland, died as a result of a traffic incident on November 30, 2019.

Authorities confirmed today his death was fire-related.

Emergency Management Commissioner Andrew Crisp said he had attended the funeral which was a "fitting tribute" to a wonderful life.

"Our thoughts and condolences go to David's widow, Judy, and family, given this tragic set of circumstances for someone who was working to keep our community safe," Mr Crisp said.

Mr Moresi was working to create containment lines when he was involved in a vehicle rollover.

Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMV) chief fire officer Chris Hardman described Mr Moresi as "a pillar of the community" and a "dedicated educator".

"He loved the bush, he inspired so many people to be in the great outdoors."

FFMV employees Mat Kavanagh, 43, and Bill Slade, 60, were killed while on the job this bushfire season.

Buchan man Mick Roberts and Maramingo Creek man Fred Becker have also died during the fires.

Mr Hardman said it had been "a very difficult year" for the organisation.

More to come.

urn:contentItem:5MNT-Y091-F0J6-J3F7-00000-00Forest Fire near Bodalla2016-11-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Forest Fire near BodallaSean Slatter

The State Forest Fire Service have spent Tuesday battling a forest fire near Bodalla.

Members of the service were called out to Nerrigundah at about 9am on Tuesday morning to the blaze, which was finally contained at about 9pm that night.

The fire was thought to have been caused by lightning in the area on Monday night.

It follows on from a grass fire in Lilli Pilli on Sunday, which the Rural Fire Service attended

Sparks from a brushcutter are believed to have caused the blaze. RFS Far South Coast Community Safety Officer Marty Webster said people needed to be wary of the conditions before operating electrical tools.

"When it is as dry as it was on the weekend, it only takes one spark," he said.

Forest Fire Management Victoria will conduct a fuel reduction burn in the Grampians starting Tuesday.

The burns will take place around Greens Creek Road, 8 kilometres north of Mirranatwa.

This burn is scheduled to be ignited between 12pm Tuesday, May, 21 and 8pm Thursday, May, 23.

The authority said road travel in the areas could be hazardous due to low visiblity from smoke, and that access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted.

urn:contentItem:5R2M-VS91-F0J6-J2D3-00000-00Busy start to early forest fire season2017-11-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Busy start to early forest fire season

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews are continuing to deal with an early and active fire season, turning out to 91 fires since last Wednesday.

Chief Fire Officer Stephanie Rotarangi said lightning had started a significant number of fires, particularly in Gippsland. "Our crews have been working hard in steep terrain and tough conditions to tackle these fires alongside Country Fire Authority firefighters," Dr Rotarangi said. "Our rappel crews have been deployed to fight fires in the high country and our firefighters with special training for arduous conditions have been busy as well," Dr Rotarangi said.

The early despatch of firefighting aircraft had also helped detect and extinguish fires, many of which were in difficult to access areas.

urn:contentItem:5SKR-4CN1-F0J6-J3R8-00000-00Dumped commercial waste frustrating Forest Fire Management Victoria2018-06-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisDumped commercial waste frustrating Forest Fire Management VictoriaChris Young

ASBESTOS sheeting, fire extinguishers and other hazardous chemical waste are increasingly being illegally dumped on public land, and Forest Fire Management Victoria has had enough.

Officers have responded to more than 20 reports of illegal rubbish in parks and forests in the last few months,.

Most troubling for Hume assistant chief fire officer Aaron Kennedy was that the waste appears to be coming from commercial businesses.

"People who dump rubbish in our forests have no regard for the health and safety of others or the environment," he said.

"These actions are putting the community at risk, which is unacceptable.

"Illegal dumpers are becoming more and more cunning, and the volumes of waste they are dumping is increasing.

"Recently, almost 200 used fire extinguishers were found dumped near the Chiltern-Mt Pilot National Park.

"We were also forced to temporarily close a popular roadside rest stop in Edi, after a large amount of asbestos sheeting was found down a disused well."

Mr Kennedy said cleanup costs were running into the thousands of dollars.

Illegal dumping can attract fines of up to $6342.

urn:contentItem:5NTJ-RD61-JC0X-K312-00000-00EUR:Portugal forest fire kills at least 242017-06-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:54:16ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSEUR:Portugal forest fire kills at least 24LISBON June 18

  A forest fire in Portugal has killed at least 24 people, most of them trapped in cars that were caught in the blaze.


   Around 20 others, including firefighters, were injured.
   The fire which sparked on Saturday is still burning out of control and is already one of the deadliest forest fires in Portugal in decades.
   Portuguese Prime Minister Antonio Costa said that the death toll had risen from 19 to 24, and that that number may yet increase.
   He defined the fire as "the worst human tragedy of recent times" to befall the country, adding that the priority now was to extinguish the fire and provide assistance to the victims.
   Many of the victims died trapped in their cars while trying to flee the blaze, whose cause was not yet known.
   In addition to the dead and injured, two people have been reported missing.
